Good morning, everybody.
So unlike many of the crypto projects out there, Ethereum
isn't really an end-to-end product.
It has always been a platform by developers for developers.
And as such, our primary task is to make developers
happy so that in their turn, they can make their end-users
happy.
Now, to achieve this, in my opinion,
one of our most important roles is to either aid
the existing tooling, developer tooling, out in the community,
or maybe fund or create new ones that the ecosystem
is currently lacking.
My talk will be about one such tool that we wrote.
But before we dive in, let's see what the actual pain point
are.
Usually, when developers approach Ethereum for the first time,
they start playing around with remix,
this browser-solidity playground.
They get the hang of solidity.
They start protecting their contract.
Now, unfortunately, quite fast, they
realize that developing in a web browser is cumbersome.
So they switch to more sophisticated tools such as
Truffle, which can do automated repeatable testing,
and also aided by proof of authority chains
or instant transactions.
Now, after developers actually finish writing their code,
usually the procedure is that they deploy it on a test net,
either Rops and/or alternative, because that's really nice.
It's a real-world environment, many users, et cetera.
Now, the problem is that this perfect testing environment
often goes belly-ock.
And the reason is-- one of the reasons
is that the test networks can be really heavy,
either due to spam attacks or to large projects,
such as radon doing intensive tests.
These can be unstable from time to time,
usually because somebody figures it
would be fun to reorganize the chain.
And lastly, it can often be unfriendly
because you have this awesome project you want to deploy,
but you don't have test ether.
And that's annoying.
And the truth is that if you are a small project,
then running testing on the test net is fine.
But if you're a bit larger project, such as radon,
or maybe have many projects such as consensus,
or perhaps you want to run a hackathon,
then the live test network isn't really ideal.
So the ideal solution is actually to run your own network.
Now, this might seem like a good idea at the beginning,
since it's light, stable, you have unlimited funds,
you can share with everybody.
But when you actually start configuring your private network,
horror strikes in.
So it's actually quite a nightmare to configure
because it has dozens of different moving components.
And so we've been working for quite a long
on a tool called Pupeth.
And our primary goal with Pupeth was actually
to run the Ringkaby test net on it.
But we kind of realized that it will be an amazing tool for--
at least we hope an amazing tool for other projects too.
So we kind of polished it up and gave it out to the community.

going to do something really crazy.
I would like to demonstrate what it
takes to actually create an entire etherium network with bells
